awd_titl_txt: Formation and Transport Dynamics of High Speed Gas-Liquid Droplet Microfluidics
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to understand liquid droplet formation and transport dynamics in gaseous microfluidic systems, including compressibility effects. Understanding liquid droplet formation and transport in gaseous microchannels will have significant impact on the general area of droplet microflows, particularly for gas sampling and dry particle aerosol generation. The knowledge gained will have major implications for next generation microfluidic systems in portable gaseous biochemical diagnostics and sensing applications, as well as in larger scale spray and atomization systems. The rich engineering, physics, and materials challenges tackled here represent a great cross-disciplinary project for the students involved. The results of the project will provide new classroom materials for courses that the PI teach, as well as outreach activities geared towards elementary school audiences. An undergraduate summer internship program aimed at underrepresented Northeastern University freshmen/sophomores will be established to prepare them as multidisciplinary leaders of future engineering challenges.

The governing physics behind the liquid droplet formation, detachment, transport, and interaction with the continuous gas phase flow for different geometries and flow conditions will be studied and analyzed. A multi-task research program will be put in place that includes hydraulic and optical diagnostics characterization of droplet formation, detachment and transport interactions, alongside numerical simulations of these processes. The research program includes the following specific thrusts: (1) Experiments and numerical simulation of droplet formation in the dripping and jetting regimes will be conducted for different flow conditions and geometries, including 3D microfluidic flow architectures. The conditions for transition between these two regimes and possible hysteresis effects will also be explored. (2) Characterization and control of the aerodynamics of droplet transport will be conducted after formation and detachment, including electrostatic based control strategies. Droplet evaporation, absorption of vapor species, and internal flow dynamics and mixing characteristics of the droplets will also be addressed. (3) An assessment will be made of the gas phase compressibility effects in terms of flow acceleration and the presence of shock waves. Changes in flow regimes and transitions as well as the droplet transport dynamics due to these effects will be assessed. Similarly, droplet interaction with standing shock waves in the microchannel will be studied.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

Fundamentally, this project has elucidated the flow and transport physics governing the geometrical parameters of the Jetting regime and the perturbation propagation conditions that lead to high speed gas-liquid droplet formation in it. The Jetting regime is characterized by the formation of a liquid thread (or jet) emanating from the liquid injection site, and which is surrounded by a gas flow in a confined co-flowing arrangement. The Jetting regime is established in a flow focusing junction microchannel geometry, where two gas flow channels flanking a liquid injection channel merge at the junction location into a main outlet microchannel, under inertia driven flow conditions.

The diameter of the jet (or liquid thread) is a function of the main outlet microchannel hydraulic diameter, ratio of the fluids (air and water in this case) flow rates, and their viscosities. To a first approximation, it can be determined by the solution of the coupled Navier-Stokes equations for the two fluids under coaxially, fully developed, laminar flow conditions. For the air-water systems tested and analyzed in this project, thread diameter was inversely proportional to the ratio of air/water flow rates.  However, more often than none the jet might not reach fully develop conditions due to droplet generation breakup, and/or the air flow can become turbulent under certain flow conditions, similarly leading to unstable liquid thread conditions.

The size of the droplets generated at the end of the liquid thread due to its breakup is slightly bigger than the jet diameter. However, due to instability and perturbations of the jet’s length and end diameter, the droplets generated tend to have a highly polydisperse (varied) size distribution. Environmental perturbations that are random in nature give rise to these jet instabilities that manifest themselves as surface waves that can propagate downstream depending on their frequency. A perturbation analysis framework for the liquid thread flow was developed and compared against actual jet diameter variation measurements over time. The agreement between the two was very good and indicated that the range and growth rate of perturbation frequencies that can propagate downstream of the jet leading to breakup and droplet generation increases with the liquid flow rate (See Figure 1). This has a paradoxical effect since higher liquid flow rates lead to faster droplet generation but at the expense of higher droplet size variability.

One last outcome of this project, related to the tradeoff between higher droplet generation rates at the expense of larger polydispersity, is the possible control of droplet size by using forced perturbations at a fixed frequency. For this purpose, a microfluidic device that integrates a lithium niobate (LiNbO3) piezoelectric chip capable of producing surface acoustic waves (SAW) was devised (See Figure 2). The LiNbO3 SAW chip is placed in the liquid injection microchannel with the aim of producing a forced perturbation at the most favorable (peak growth rate) frequency. The idea is that this forced perturbation would be the dominant one and swamp the other possible perturbations that can propagate downstream of the jet, leading to more uniform droplet generation.

The experimental and analytical work performed during the lifetime of the project has been presented at several domestic and international seminars and conferences.

Broader Impact:

The knowledge gained in terms of flow and transport physics of high-speed gas-liquid droplet formation in the Jetting regime has significant impact in the general area of droplet microfluidics with major implications for next generation microfluidic systems in portable gaseous biochemical diagnostics and sensing applications, as well as in larger scale spray and atomization systems, where understanding of these microscale dynamics is desirable.  

In addition, the problems that were tackled in this cross-disciplinary project presented rich engineering, physics, and materials challenges to the graduate and undergraduate students involved. Each of the different participants on the project team had an area of specialty (i.e. experimental setup design and instrumentation, micromanufacturing, and image processing and visualization), and as they worked together they mutually taught and mentored each other in their particular areas of knowledge and expertise. Besides the technical knowledge gained by the participants, their interactions enhanced their collaboration and team working skills. Similarly, they were trained in communication and presentation skills through the oral presentations they conducted. All the students involved attended weekly individual meetings with the PI. Each student also presented once or twice a semester as part of the PI’s research group weekly meetings. Finally, the PI ensured that at all levels the students were exposed to a mentoring scheme that allowed them not only to receive but also to provide guidance to a fellow project member. 

The project provided training and financial support for two (2) Ph.D. students along their graduate studies at Northeastern University. In addition to the Ph.D. students, one (1) M.S. student and several undergraduate students were involved in this project.

 


Last Modified: 01/29/2024
Modified by: Carlos H Hidrovo Chavez

    Carlos Hidrovo Chavez, Zihao Meng

(c) Exploded view of the PDMS layers and SAW chip of the 3D gas-liquid droplet microfluidic system. (d) Assembled SAW chip integrated 3D gas-liquid droplet microfluidic system.
    Carlos Hidrovo Chavez, Zihao Meng
    Copyrighted
